newsitem.title: GERMANY: ZEITLER-NO SIGN OF CHANGE IN CAPITAL MKTS TREND.
newsitem.headline: ZEITLER-NO SIGN OF CHANGE IN CAPITAL MKTS TREND.

text.p: Bundesbank council member Franz-Christoph Zeitler said on Monday there was no sign of a change in trend in German capital market rates.

Zeitler, who is president of the Bavarian state central bank, also told reporters at a meeting of bankers and entrepreneurs that Germany was back on track for growth but that the growth was not yet "exuberant."
"Germany has returned to the growth path but the growth is not exuberant," Zeitler said.
He added that he expected real growth of just above one percent for 1996.

Referring to the September M3 data released earlier on Monday, Zeitler said the data underscored the Bundesbank's "steady hand" policy on interest rates. German money supply growth was moving in the direction of the Bundesbank's target range for 1996 of four to seven percent, he said.
"I want to leave it open, whether the corridor will be reached in December or in the early months of 1997," he said.
September M3 annualised growth, the Bundesbank's main policy indicator, slowed marginally to 8.4 percent after climbing to 8.7 percent in August.
